title: The Wealth of Stewardship
devotional:
Old Mr. Abernathy ran the town's hardware store for as long as anyone could remember. He was a fixture, a kind face dispensing wisdom and nails with equal measure. But Mr. Abernathy wasn't just good at selling hardware; he had an uncanny knack for using his resources to bless others. He quietly fixed leaky roofs for widows who couldn't afford it, donated supplies to the local soup kitchen, and always had a kind word and a helping hand for those in need. He wasn't rich, but he was incredibly wealthy in the ways that truly mattered.

One day, a young man named David came to Mr. Abernathy, complaining about his lack of opportunity. "I just don't have anything to work with," David lamented. Mr. Abernathy smiled, pulled out a small, tarnished silver coin from his pocket, and handed it to David. "Here," he said. "This is all I have to spare right now. Use it wisely."

David scoffed. "What can I possibly do with this?" But Mr. Abernathy simply replied, "That's for you to discover. Remember, it's not the amount you have, but what you do with it that counts."

David, feeling dejected but strangely compelled, took the coin. After much thought, he decided to buy a small bag of apple seeds. He spent his days planting them in a vacant lot on the edge of town. He nurtured those seedlings, tending to them with care and dedication. Years passed, and David's small apple orchard flourished. He provided fresh fruit to the community, created jobs, and even started a small cider-making business. He returned to Mr. Abernathy, not with the tarnished coin, but with a basket overflowing with apples, a testament to the power of stewardship.

David learned that day that true wealth isn't measured in dollars and cents, but in the way we use what we've been given to bless others and glorify God. We all have resources, whether time, talent, or treasure. The question is, how are we using them?
image_description: A close-up of a gnarled hand holding a single tarnished silver coin in a sunlit hardware store, with shelves of tools and supplies blurred in the background.
insights: The parable of the talents in Matthew 25:14-30 underscores the importance of responsible stewardship. Each servant was entrusted with talents 'according to his ability,' and those who used their talents wisely were rewarded, while the one who buried his talent was condemned. This illustrates that God expects us to actively use the gifts and resources He has given us, regardless of how small or insignificant they may seem. 1 Peter 4:10 reminds us, 'As each has received a gift, use it to serve one another, as good stewards of God's varied grace.'
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the abundance of blessings you have bestowed upon me. Forgive me for the times I have hoarded my resources, fearing scarcity or seeking personal gain. Help me to recognize the gifts and talents you have entrusted to me and to use them wisely and generously for the benefit of others and the glory of your name. Teach me to be a faithful steward of all that you have given me, knowing that everything I have comes from you. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: What resources (time, talent, treasure) has God entrusted to you? Are you using them to their fullest potential? What is one practical step you can take this week to be a better steward of what God has given you?
